title: 109_s2830
content: The Act may be cited as the "Corporate Average Fuel Economy Reform Act of 2006" and includes standards for passenger automobiles. The "Corporate Average Fuel Economy Reform Act of 2006" amends Section 32902 of title 49, United States Code, to require the Secretary of Transportation to set average fuel economy standards for passenger automobiles before each model year. The standards must be the maximum feasible level achievable by manufacturers, with the option to set separate standards for different classes of passenger automobiles. The Secretary must ensure that manufacturers meet fuel economy standards set by the Corporate Average Fuel Economy Reform Act of 2006. The Secretary has the authority to set standards based on vehicle attributes and express them mathematically for one or more model years. The Secretary has the authority to set fuel economy standards for one or more model years, with required lead-time and no across-the-board increases. Additionally, motor vehicle safety and emissions are included in the standards. The Secretary of Transportation has the authority to set fuel economy standards for model years, with input from the Department of Energy and the Environmental Protection Agency. The standards aim to reduce dependence on oil for transportation and consider conservation goals. The Secretary of Transportation can set fuel economy standards for model years with input from the Department of Energy and the Environmental Protection Agency. If the proposed standard or amendment does not align with conservation or environmental protection goals, the Secretary or Administrator can provide written comments. Before finalizing a standard or exemption, the Secretary of Transportation must notify the Department of Energy and the Environmental Protection Agency for their input. The Secretary of Transportation may not set fuel economy standards that impose costs exceeding benefits. Amendments are made to exemption criteria for manufacturers requesting exemptions. Conforming amendments are made to title 49, United States Code. Amendments are made to title 49, United States Code regarding fuel economy standards, exemption criteria for manufacturers, and conforming amendments. Amendments to title 49, United States Code include changes to sections 32904(a)(1)(B), 32909(b), and 32917(b)(1)(B) regarding fuel economy standards and filing deadlines. SEC. 3. USE OF EARNED CREDITS. Section 32903 of title 49, United States Code is amended to extend the consecutive model years from 3 to 5. The Secretary of Transportation may allow credit transfers for manufacturers of automobiles between passenger-automobile and non-passenger-automobile production segments. The Secretary of Transportation may allow credit transfers for manufacturers between passenger-automobile and non-passenger-automobile production to incentivize more efficient vehicles and domestic automotive employment. Section 32912 of title 49, United States Code, is amended to allow all civil penalties to be used for a research program on fuel-saving automotive technologies and to support rulemaking for the corporate average fuel economy program. The Act and its amendments take effect upon enactment, with a transition period for passenger automobile standards until a new standard is issued. The Secretary of Transportation must initiate rulemaking for passenger automobiles within 60 days of enactment. The Act mandates the amendment of fuel economy standards for passenger automobiles until a final rule is issued by the Secretary of Transportation.
